alignments.summary: Communities define the epistemologies and protocols that shape their tooling.
alignments.submission_title: Sacred Stacks and Post-Extractive Dev Environments
alignments.submission_overview: Sacred Stacks is an effort to build software environments that reframe code and digital infrastructure as sacred, relational practice. It proposes a post-extractive model of development where communities can co-create and maintain digital tools grounded in ceremony, kinship, and long-term care. Rather than maximizing speed or efficiency, these environments prioritize collective authorship, slow knowledge, and epistemic sovereignty. Dev environments become cultural environments. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3

alignments.summary: Enhances control over the interface layer.
alignments.submission_title: Shared Tray Protocol for Coordinated Overlay Interfaces
alignments.submission_overview:
I propose the development of a browser-level interface protocol that allows multiple overlays (e.g. assistants, wallets, chat tools) to register themselves into a shared, user-configurable tray, typically anchored in the lower-right corner of the screen. This would support coexistence of decentralized tools, prevent UX collisions, and empower users to customize their digital environment without friction.

Overlays would be able to:
- Register a “startup icon” and metadata (name, role, permissions)
- Indicate availability or priority
- Respect a shared system for tray placement and visibility
- Defer to user preferences in display and ordering

Users could:
- Configure which overlays are pinned or expanded
- Access others on demand via an expandable tray
- Rely on consistent placement and behavior across sites and browsers

Next Steps: I suggest forming a W3C Community Group to define an open standard for overlay registration and tray coordination. This standard could help browsers and web apps harmonize decentralized UI layers, supporting both open innovation and excellent UX.

alignments.summary: Reframes friction and moderation as tools for self-guided reflection and norm alignment.
alignments.submission_title: Cultivating Trust in AI-Assisted Online Conversations
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes a values-based framework for moderation, reputation, and friction in AI-mediated online discourse. Instead of punitive moderation, the system introduces soft interventions such as modulated visibility and reflection cues. These tools promote respectful, legible, and community-aligned interactions. The design treats moderation as a participatory, adaptive mechanism shaped by community values. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: User-created paths and tools empower navigational authorship and customization.
alignments.submission_title: Navigator User Interfaces (NUI) as a Coordination Layer for a Post-Search, Post-Feed Web
alignments.submission_overview: This submission introduces Navigator User Interfaces (NUIs) as a new standard for customizable, shareable navigation tools across web-based tasks, educational flows, and collaborative work. NUIs propose a federated ecosystem of navigation frameworks allowing pluralistic learning, interaction, and AI-guided exploration, grounded in a shared regular panel. This enables remixable workflows while supporting agency, privacy, transparency, and ethical alignment. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Proposes delegated agency controls, allowing users to oversee their representative agents.
alignments.submission_title: Minimum Protocol for Responsible Interaction Between Autonomous Agents
alignments.submission_overview: With the rapid expansion of autonomous agents—both personal and corporate—there is an urgent need for a minimal protocol that enables these agents to interact visibly, responsibly, and semantically coherently with websites, interfaces, and each other. This submission proposes structural Meta-layer support for these interactions via observable traces, standard formats, and distributed authentication mechanisms. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Empowers users to choose decentralized storage locations like IPFS as a form of digital self-determination.
alignments.submission_title: Save As to Web3: A UX Gateway to Decentralized Storage
alignments.submission_overview: This proposal upgrades the familiar 'save as...' functionality into a Web3-native interaction—allowing users to save files directly to decentralized cloud storage such as IPFS. By embedding decentralized storage options into user interfaces, this approach enables user agency and sovereignty without requiring technical knowledge. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Empowers users to control data, emotional permissions, and sensory inputs.
alignments.submission_title: Security Protocols and Ethical Safeguards in the Lyra System
alignments.submission_overview: This submission distills the architecture and protective mechanisms of the Lyra System—a privacy-centric, emotionally intelligent interface—focusing on its multi-layered approach to identity security, data sovereignty, ethical data handling, and emotional consent. Lyra integrates decentralized identity protocols, local storage autonomy, soulbound emotional markers, and open governance to establish a radically secure and self-protective environment. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3

alignments.summary: Emphasizes tools and standards that allow Global South participants to engage on their own terms, not dictated by legacy systems.
alignments.submission_title: Ethical Products for the Global South
alignments.submission_overview: This submission highlights two interlinked challenges: (1) current blockchain and Web3 product models are prohibitively expensive and culturally misaligned for crafts-producing communities in the Global South; (2) lack of interoperable standards risks reinforcing digital colonialism and undermining transformative policies like the EU's Green Deal. The author calls for early standardization and native interoperability, particularly around Digital Product Passports (DPPs), to empower bottom-up adoption and avoid top-down imposition. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Encourages individuals to become surfers—curators of the web—reclaiming control over discovery.
alignments.submission_title: Can Directories Rise Again?
alignments.submission_overview: This submission reflects on the current deteriorating state of web search, emphasizing how AI-generated content and algorithmic prioritization have reduced the human-centric experience of exploration. It draws parallels with the early days of Yahoo! and its surfer-driven directories to propose a revival of decentralized, point-of-view-rich human directories. These directories, distributed across communities rather than centralized institutions, can rekindle authentic discovery and trust online. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Enables individuals to authorize or limit agent actions based on ethically contextualized boundaries aligned with sentience and consent.
alignments.submission_title: Forensic Transparency and 'The Creed': A Dual Framework for Ethical Digital Presence
alignments.submission_overview: This submission introduces two interrelated proposals. The first defines 'Forensic Transparency' as a principle where investigations involving personal data are constrained within a trusted quartet of systems, preserving user privacy while enabling traceability. The second introduces a value-aligned digital agent architecture guided by a framework called 'The Creed'—a seven-point ethical system designed to support decision-making in dynamic or morally complex contexts. Together, these concepts promote conditional accountability, ethical deliberation, and adaptable system design. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3

alignments.summary: Encourages sovereign interpretation and self-determined learning through epistemic scaffolding.
alignments.submission_title: Sixteen Axioms for Cognitive Infrastructure
alignments.submission_overview: This submission offers a distilled suite of sixteen axioms designed to serve as a foundational cognitive infrastructure for the Meta-Layer. These axioms form a substrate for adaptive learning, perception, and tool creation across shifting contexts. Rather than prescribing behavior, they cultivate interpretive strength—guiding participants toward clarity, coherence, and sovereign insight in their engagements with the unknown. These lines may inform curriculum, protocol design, AI-human interfaces, and participatory governance by anchoring development in composable, pluralistic wisdom. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3

alignments.summary: Individuals can mint, sign, challenge, or verify named objects across contexts without reliance on a single platform.
alignments.submission_title: Name Chain–Anchored Digital Artifacts with Interoperable Authentication Marks
alignments.submission_overview: This pattern enables any digital object—text, credential, file, token—to carry a human-readable name (e.g., @name/object) and a verifiable, interoperable mark of authentication. These objects can travel across the open web while retaining provenance, trust context, and actionable semantics. The system allows for persistent identity, cross-platform verification, and composability of trustable content, providing a semantic envelope for use in overlays, presence layers, or public ledgers. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3. This submission was inspired by a conversation with Jaime Schwartz about his name chain and provenance tech.

alignments.summary: Users hold their own keys, control their identities, and can securely communicate without intermediaries.
alignments.submission_title: Towards Decentralized Applications: Rethinking Control Power and Data Exchange in Named-Data Networking
alignments.submission_overview: This submission presents a comprehensive framework and prototype for decentralized applications built on Named-Data Networking (NDN), aimed at resolving centralization in control power over user data, identity, and communications. Through the design, implementation, and evaluation of "NDN Workspace," the work demonstrates how semantic naming, data-centric security, and distributed data synchronization can enable direct, secure, and serverless peer-to-peer collaboration. The study also contributes critical insights into naming schemes, trust schema enforcement, and the broader ecosystem architecture required to support real-time collaborative applications outside the cloud paradigm. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Nordfors's VeMe model and Lambert's story-driven AI place agency in the hands of individuals, not platforms.
alignments.submission_title: The Engineer's Ledger and the People-Centered Paraidox
alignments.submission_overview: This submission presents a multifaceted synthesis of perspectives from an i4j town hall that explored how AI can serve human flourishing through pragmatic design, data dignity, and civic accountability. From Vint Cerf's empirical assessments to David Nordfors's VeMe concept, and from creative industry safeguards to behavioral science in HR, the discussion mapped the contours of a people-centered AI paradigm. The convergence across sectors—tech, policy, education, and entertainment—suggests a reframing of the so-called Paraidox: embracing AI to enhance, not replace, human intelligence. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3 and is based on the i4j town hall 'Harnessing AI for Productivity and Meaningful Work.'

alignments.summary: Defines what 'agency' means for non-human agents, especially those with action vectors and AI autonomy.
alignments.submission_title: Governance for Advanced Non-Human Agents and AI Systems
alignments.submission_overview: Based on Dr. Paul John Werbos's Saving the World and New Jerusalem posts, this submission proposes clarifications and extensions to numerous Desirable Properties to account for the governance, authentication, and accountability of advanced non-human agents and AI systems, including those that may operate in physical or hybrid embodiments, participate in economic systems, or manage critical infrastructure. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Empowers users to understand and control how their data is collected and shared.
alignments.submission_title: AI-Augmented Data Visibility for Safer Web Experiences
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes an AI-augmented tool (e.g., a browser extension or embedded prototype) that transparently reveals what data is being collected and tracked during web interactions. It aims to equip users with actionable insight into data flows and help mitigate exploitative ad-based surveillance. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: VeMe and story-driven AI models center user agency over platform dominance.
alignments.submission_title: The Engineer's Ledger and the People-Centered Paraidox
alignments.submission_overview: This submission presents a multifaceted synthesis of perspectives from an i4j town hall that explored how AI can serve human flourishing through pragmatic design, data dignity, and civic accountability. From Vint Cerf's empirical assessments to David Nordfors's VeMe concept, and from creative industry safeguards to behavioral science in HR, the discussion mapped the contours of a people-centered AI paradigm. The convergence across sectors—tech, policy, education, and entertainment—suggests a reframing of the so-called Paraidox: embracing AI to enhance, not replace, human intelligence. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3 and is based on the i4j town hall 'Harnessing AI for Productivity and Meaningful Work.'

alignments.summary: Empowers learners by formalizing their informal, non-traditional, or experiential learning into portable credentials.
alignments.submission_title: Global Recognition of Prior Learning via Meta-Layer Credentials
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes a standardized extension of Recognition of Previous Learning (RPL) by leveraging the badge-based credentialing system of the Meta-Layer. The objective is to create a globally verifiable, interoperable framework that educational institutions can universally recognize, enabling learners to carry validated learning achievements across jurisdictions and systems. The initiative encourages integration with existing academic accreditation bodies while preserving decentralized verification and learner agency. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3

alignments.summary: The Meta-Layer expands individual freedom and agency by facilitating access to knowledge, communication, and mutual aid unconstrained by socio-economic, geographic, political, or ideological repression.
alignments.submission_title: Levelling the Digital Playing Field: A Meta-Layer for a Post-Capitalist Web
alignments.submission_overview: The web should serve as a planetary commons, empowering individuals rather than extending the dominance of governments or corporate interests. Instead of fueling extractive capitalist agendas, it must foster community resilience and global solidarity. This submission proposes a meta-layer that reorients the web toward cooperative engagement: connecting those in need with those able to help, and enabling flows of knowledge, support, and solutions across divisive boundaries. By doing so, it reclaims the web as a site of mutual aid and regenerative exchange. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Empowers users to choose, combine, and remove reputation providers according to their preferences, without vendor interference.
alignments.submission_title: Chromium Reputation Provider Framework: A Decentralized Reputation Layer for the Web
alignments.submission_overview: This draft proposal from the Chromium team outlines a browser-native framework enabling users to install, manage, and utilize multiple independent reputation providers. It envisions a decentralized ecosystem for reputational signals, facilitating both positive and negative assessments of websites and content. This approach prioritizes user choice, system resilience, and reputational pluralism over centralized moderation or gatekeeping by browser vendors. It aims to replicate the utility of walled-garden trust systems (e.g., Amazon reviews) while retaining the open and user-controlled nature of the web. The framework proposes multiple technical mechanisms for secure and privacy-respecting attestations, enabling scalable and nuanced integration of reputational data into browsing experiences. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Empowers students as researchers and contributors, enabling them to shape digital narratives and collaborate internationally on meaningful issues.
alignments.submission_title: Seeding Generational Familiarity with the Meta-Layer Through Purpose-Driven Educational Use
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes a pathway to introduce the Meta-Layer and the Overweb to large youth demographics—particularly through educational institutions in Europe—by integrating its tools into project-based learning. Schools frequently face challenges in teaching safe and meaningful digital participation, often within bleak discussions around bullying, misinformation, and online harm. Offering students a platform that actively embodies the ideals of safe, collaborative, and transparent internet use transforms these discussions into hopeful explorations. Through international student projects on topics like sustainable development, cultural heritage, or local youth leadership, learners could engage with the Meta-Layer's truth-marking tools and bridge systems over time. These students would gain years of formative experience with purpose-aligned digital tools, anchoring future internet use in trust, clarity, and collaborative agency. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Enables both students and journalists to actively contribute to truth-marking and bridge-building that shape public understanding.
alignments.submission_title: Seeding Generational Familiarity with the Meta-Layer Through Purpose-Driven Educational Use and Scandinavian Journalism Partnerships
alignments.submission_overview: Early Use Case Scandinavian Journalism Newsrooms combined with Seeding Generational Familiarity through Purpose-Driven Use in Education. This submission proposes a dual-entry approach to introduce the Meta-Layer and the Overweb to broad audiences by focusing on two interrelated use cases: education and journalism. First, in the school sector—particularly across Europe—project-based learning environments can integrate Meta-Layer tools to foster youth engagement with a safer, purpose-driven, and participatory web. Second, Scandinavia represents a particularly fertile region for a journalist-specific integration of the Meta-Layer. With strong traditions of collaborative civic culture, peaceful education systems, and relatively depolarized journalism ecosystems, countries like Denmark and Sweden could pioneer the use of a dedicated journalistic layer. This would empower newsrooms to verify content, trace sources, and resist the creep of misinformation. These use cases are mutually reinforcing and could provide a resilient first foothold for broader adoption. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Empowers youth and parents alike to shape online experiences collaboratively rather than being passive consumers.
alignments.submission_title: Family-Centered Introduction of the Meta-Layer for Safer, Co-Creative Internet Engagement
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes a public introduction strategy for the Meta-Layer and the Overweb that centers on families—parents, children, and teenagers—by addressing their everyday digital challenges and aspirations. It emphasizes trust-based engagement over restriction, promoting an environment where youth can safely explore, learn, and contribute meaningfully to the co-creation of digital culture. Rather than pursuing institutional entry points (e.g., via schools or governments), this strategy focuses on engaging family media—parenting magazines, youth outlets, school take-home materials—with an invitation to participate. The initiative envisions the Meta-Layer as a viable alternative to the corporate internet, providing young people with a healthier, more creative, and civically empowered online life. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: LGBTQ+ users must be able to express identity and participate in digital life without fear of erasure or discrimination.
alignments.submission_title: Platform Harms to LGBTQ+ Communities and the Need for Inclusive Meta-Layer Design
alignments.submission_overview: The March 2024 Kairos Fellowship report, User Error: LGBTQ+, documents historical and ongoing harms experienced by LGBTQ+ individuals in digital environments, with emphasis on the erasure and marginalization caused by platform policies and automated moderation systems. Drawing from this analysis, this submission argues for the incorporation of inclusive design principles into the Meta-Layer Initiative, particularly those that protect vulnerable populations. Key recommendations include increasing transparency, empowering community-based governance, and ensuring AI systems respect identity and context. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3 https://static1.squarespace.com/static/580a3e6403596e9f6d5a46bf/t/65f1fd44c0590a0681dc4cea/1710357856560/Kairos_UserError-LGBTQ

alignments.summary: Enables citizens to co-create and govern digital public infrastructure within their municipalities.
alignments.submission_title: Meta-Layer as Municipal Infrastructure: European Cities as Pioneering Use Case
alignments.submission_overview: This submission proposes that development of the Meta-Layer begin with a targeted pilot in European municipalities. Unlike the U.S., many European cities retain civic trust and robust public funding. Recent German policy dialogues show alignment with the Meta-Layer's civic tools. Municipalities could deploy the Meta-Layer for feedback systems, participatory governance, youth digital literacy, and cross-regional collaboration. The proposal imagines Meta-Layer adoption as a digital public commons co-owned by cities and their citizens, providing a foundation for regional democratic resilience. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Semantic agents optimize outcomes like healthcare by dynamically negotiating user-defined constraints, preserving autonomy.
alignments.submission_title: Enabling Machine-Readable Meaning through the Semantic Web
alignments.submission_overview: This submission revisits the seminal 2001 vision of the Semantic Web, proposing its relevance and expanded applicability to modern decentralized meta-systems. It explores how the foundational architecture of the Semantic Web—built on distributed knowledge representation, interoperable ontologies, and machine-readable logic—prefigures the infrastructure needed for scalable, composable, and user-aligned digital environments. The submission identifies alignment with multiple Desirable Properties, especially regarding knowledge portability, participatory governance, and ethical agentic systems. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

alignments.summary: Empowers users with progressive disclosure, focus modes, informed defaults, and data control dashboards.
alignments.submission_title: Humane Design Patterns for Ethical Tech Platforms
alignments.submission_overview: This submission synthesizes practical interface and architectural patterns from the 'Humane Tech Framework' to inform the development of platforms that enhance user agency, attention, relationships, and understanding. The design patterns tackle common harms such as compulsive usage, information overload, and manipulative defaults by emphasizing user wellbeing, transparency, and ethical engagement. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3 https://github.com/ErikaOnFire/humane-tech-framework/blob/main/docs/design-patterns.md

alignments.summary: Emphasizes human creators' loss of control and visibility in an AI-dominated content ecosystem.
alignments.submission_title: The Algorithmic Collapse: Reclaiming Humanity in the Age of AI Slop
alignments.submission_overview: This submission critiques the current trajectory of internet culture, shaped by a deluge of AI-generated content that mimics human creativity without its soul. It raises alarms about the degradation of trust, the erosion of digital authenticity, and the weaponization of engagement algorithms. It also highlights the need for systemic reevaluation: how we value creative labor, what constitutes "real" content, and the risks of unchecked AI proliferation in social, artistic, and journalistic domains. The human internet is not dead—but it's under siege. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.

clarifications.title: Overlay Autonomy via Interface Preferences
clarifications.why_it_matters: Agency at the interface level increases usability and inclusivity, especially when decentralized tools proliferate.
clarifications.submission_title: Shared Tray Protocol for Coordinated Overlay Interfaces
clarifications.submission_overview:
I propose the development of a browser-level interface protocol that allows multiple overlays (e.g. assistants, wallets, chat tools) to register themselves into a shared, user-configurable tray, typically anchored in the lower-right corner of the screen. This would support coexistence of decentralized tools, prevent UX collisions, and empower users to customize their digital environment without friction.

Overlays would be able to:
- Register a “startup icon” and metadata (name, role, permissions)
- Indicate availability or priority
- Respect a shared system for tray placement and visibility
- Defer to user preferences in display and ordering

Users could:
- Configure which overlays are pinned or expanded
- Access others on demand via an expandable tray
- Rely on consistent placement and behavior across sites and browsers

Next Steps: I suggest forming a W3C Community Group to define an open standard for overlay registration and tray coordination. This standard could help browsers and web apps harmonize decentralized UI layers, supporting both open innovation and excellent UX.
clarifications.clarification: User interface autonomy is extended to the tray layer, giving users the ability to manage and curate their engagement with decentralized tools.

clarifications.title: Reflective Moderation as Empowerment
clarifications.why_it_matters: Promotes autonomy while guiding social responsibility.
clarifications.submission_title: Cultivating Trust in AI-Assisted Online Conversations
clarifications.submission_overview: This submission proposes a values-based framework for moderation, reputation, and friction in AI-mediated online discourse. Instead of punitive moderation, the system introduces soft interventions such as modulated visibility and reflection cues. These tools promote respectful, legible, and community-aligned interactions. The design treats moderation as a participatory, adaptive mechanism shaped by community values. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
clarifications.clarification: Friction-based tools should invite user introspection and growth, rather than impose constraints.

clarifications.title: Emotional Consent as a First-Class Protocol
clarifications.why_it_matters: Extends self-sovereignty to affective domains, upholding human dignity in emotionally aware systems.
clarifications.submission_title: Security Protocols and Ethical Safeguards in the Lyra System
clarifications.submission_overview: This submission distills the architecture and protective mechanisms of the Lyra System—a privacy-centric, emotionally intelligent interface—focusing on its multi-layered approach to identity security, data sovereignty, ethical data handling, and emotional consent. Lyra integrates decentralized identity protocols, local storage autonomy, soulbound emotional markers, and open governance to establish a radically secure and self-protective environment. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3
clarifications.clarification: Lyra lets users control not just data access but also biometric sensing and emotional computation.

clarifications.title: Defining Agency for AI and Systems
clarifications.why_it_matters: To ensure the Meta-layer accommodates AGI entities as coherent participants with defined roles.
clarifications.submission_title: Governance for Advanced Non-Human Agents and AI Systems
clarifications.submission_overview: Based on Dr. Paul John Werbos's Saving the World and New Jerusalem posts, this submission proposes clarifications and extensions to numerous Desirable Properties to account for the governance, authentication, and accountability of advanced non-human agents and AI systems, including those that may operate in physical or hybrid embodiments, participate in economic systems, or manage critical infrastructure. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
clarifications.clarification: Define what 'agency' means for non-human agents, especially those with action vectors and AI autonomy.

clarifications.title: Semantic Delegation via Autonomous Agents
clarifications.why_it_matters: This structure supports scaled autonomy while preserving participant agency in increasingly automated systems.
clarifications.submission_title: Enabling Machine-Readable Meaning through the Semantic Web
clarifications.submission_overview: This submission revisits the seminal 2001 vision of the Semantic Web, proposing its relevance and expanded applicability to modern decentralized meta-systems. It explores how the foundational architecture of the Semantic Web—built on distributed knowledge representation, interoperable ontologies, and machine-readable logic—prefigures the infrastructure needed for scalable, composable, and user-aligned digital environments. The submission identifies alignment with multiple Desirable Properties, especially regarding knowledge portability, participatory governance, and ethical agentic systems. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
clarifications.clarification: Delegation architecture empowers agents to act within user-defined preferences and trust parameters without removing human control.

extensions.title: Path Authorship and Remixing as User Empowerment
extensions.why_it_matters: Gives agency over how tools are used, shared, and adapted.
extensions.submission_title: Navigator User Interfaces (NUI) as a Coordination Layer for a Post-Search, Post-Feed Web
extensions.submission_overview: This submission introduces Navigator User Interfaces (NUIs) as a new standard for customizable, shareable navigation tools across web-based tasks, educational flows, and collaborative work. NUIs propose a federated ecosystem of navigation frameworks allowing pluralistic learning, interaction, and AI-guided exploration, grounded in a shared regular panel. This enables remixable workflows while supporting agency, privacy, transparency, and ethical alignment. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Users should be able to author and fork navigational flows with fine-grained control.

extensions.title: Delegated Agency with User Controls
extensions.why_it_matters: Allows meaningful automation while preserving user intent and oversight.
extensions.submission_title: Minimum Protocol for Responsible Interaction Between Autonomous Agents
extensions.submission_overview: With the rapid expansion of autonomous agents—both personal and corporate—there is an urgent need for a minimal protocol that enables these agents to interact visibly, responsibly, and semantically coherently with websites, interfaces, and each other. This submission proposes structural Meta-layer support for these interactions via observable traces, standard formats, and distributed authentication mechanisms. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: The Meta-layer should enable users to delegate authority to autonomous agents, with explicit control over their actions.

extensions.title: User-Directed Decentralized Storage
extensions.why_it_matters: Empowers individuals with tangible choices over data control and fosters engagement with decentralized tools.
extensions.submission_title: Save As to Web3: A UX Gateway to Decentralized Storage
extensions.submission_overview: This proposal upgrades the familiar 'save as...' functionality into a Web3-native interaction—allowing users to save files directly to decentralized cloud storage such as IPFS. By embedding decentralized storage options into user interfaces, this approach enables user agency and sovereignty without requiring technical knowledge. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: Explicitly support user-directed storage destinations (e.g., IPFS) within the Meta-layer stack.

extensions.title: Civic-Scale Digital Co-Creation
extensions.why_it_matters: City-level digital infrastructure often excludes citizen control and excludes co-ownership by municipalities. This approach redefines 'users' as civic partners with real agency in shaping and owning public infrastructure.
extensions.submission_title: Meta-Layer as Municipal Infrastructure: European Cities as Pioneering Use Case
extensions.submission_overview: This submission proposes that development of the Meta-Layer begin with a targeted pilot in European municipalities. Unlike the U.S., many European cities retain civic trust and robust public funding. Recent German policy dialogues show alignment with the Meta-Layer's civic tools. Municipalities could deploy the Meta-Layer for feedback systems, participatory governance, youth digital literacy, and cross-regional collaboration. The proposal imagines Meta-Layer adoption as a digital public commons co-owned by cities and their citizens, providing a foundation for regional democratic resilience. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3.
extensions.extension: The proposal extends the scope of 'participant agency' from individual platform users to civic actors, such as municipalities and regional coalitions, enabling them to co-develop and customize the municipal layer of the Meta-Layer.

extensions.title: Humane Defaults and Progressive Interfaces
extensions.why_it_matters: Empowerment is not only about offering control, but about making that control understandable, accessible, and non-exploitative. These patterns address the structural design of how agency is experienced.
extensions.submission_title: Humane Design Patterns for Ethical Tech Platforms
extensions.submission_overview: This submission synthesizes practical interface and architectural patterns from the 'Humane Tech Framework' to inform the development of platforms that enhance user agency, attention, relationships, and understanding. The design patterns tackle common harms such as compulsive usage, information overload, and manipulative defaults by emphasizing user wellbeing, transparency, and ethical engagement. This submission was generated with protocol META-DP-EVAL-v1.3 https://github.com/ErikaOnFire/humane-tech-framework/blob/main/docs/design-patterns.md
extensions.extension: This proposal extends the interpretation of agency to include interface architectures that reduce cognitive burden, promote user-led configuration, and avoid dark patterns. This includes progressive disclosure of settings, focus-enabling modes, and defaults aligned with user wellbeing rather than engagement maximization.
